Security Theater.title: Deep fake it till you make it!
Security Theater.abstract: Deep fake it till you make it is a continuation of a talk i did at Häjysec in Vaasa, The concept is to look at the evolution of AI and it's implications, the talk is humourous in nature and involves several demos.
Security Theater.description:
This presentation takes the audience on a captivating journey through the evolution of artificial intelligence, blending personal anecdotes, philosophical exploration, and live technical demonstrations. We'll delve into the speaker's experiences growing up alongside technology, from the birth of home computers to the mind-boggling capabilities of today's AI.

We'll tackle big questions about AI's potential, touching on utopian and dystopian visions, the technological singularity, and the "Vulnerable World Hypothesis." Live demos will showcase the power and potential pitfalls of AI, including voice cloning, deepfakes, and AI-generated content.

Through humor and thought-provoking insights, the presentation will leave the audience with a deeper understanding of AI's impact on our world and a newfound appreciation for its possibilities and perils.

"It's rare to see a presenter that combines technical content and humour in the way Ross does. As a strong believer in that combining tech with entertainment will end up with attendees learning more than just forcing education at them, I can highly recommend Ross' sessions for anyone." Sami Laiho

persons.biography:
Over 20 years in IT,  currently working as Lead for OT Cyber Security in Fortum, British and I have lived in FInland for the last 10 years.

**Widest** face on google search

Cyber Security “expert”

OT Cyber Security, Cyber engagement, AI, threat intelligence and cyber operations.

Security Theater.title: Staying Sneaky in Microsoft Azure
Security Theater.abstract:
Microsoft are improving their cloud platform by providing more log sources that can be consumed to gain visibility into enumeration and data read events. However, due to Azure's complexity, such as different legacy and modern systems, the same objective can be achieved by an attacker through different methods, inherently with different indicators. As a result, the challenges that organisations face, and will continue on facing, are the following:

- Attackers using known and lesser-known APIs to perform activities against a tenant and Azure resources.
- Attackers remaining undetected due to assumptions taken by defensive teams in how specific attacks would be performed.

This talk will aim to build up on publicly available research into undocumented APIs within Azure and present different ways that attackers can use these APIs to gather information about an environment and also perform actions against the estate. With each method that is discussed, the talk will also present what controls exist to try and prevent their abuse within an organisation as well as what telemetry is generated when performing these attacks. Thus, allowing attendees to understand the available attack surface within Azure and help provide guidance on the potential non-typical log sources that should be ingested to improve an attack detection in an estate.
Security Theater.description:
General structure of the slides will be the following:

Will begin with an introduction to the topic of the different APIs that exist within Azure/Entra. This is to give enough context to all people in the audience and set the scene for how these APIs interact with each other. This will then be followed up with an explanation of the particular APIs that will be shown which will be the Ibiza API and the PIM API within Entra/Azure. 

Lastly the talk will move to a simulated/example case study from the perspective of a compromised user in Entra. First usage of the more well-known Microsoft Graph API will be shown to showcase that logs are indeed generated for read/enumeration events there within Entra. Then equivalent user enumeration actions will be performed using the other APIs in order to show that logs would not be generated from those APIs while still providing similar information as the Graph API. 

Talk will then finish up with a primer on the available recommendations on how to tackle this challenge from a defender's perspective and where effort should be focused. And then finish with an overall summary.

For full disclosure, as the talk was presented at fwd:cloudsec EU 2024 the slides from the original version can be found here for evaluation purposes and consideration for the conference (https://fwdcloudsec.org/assets/presentations/2024/europe/christian-philipov-staying-sneaky-in-azure.pdf). 

The slides should largely remain similar but with the additional time am considering expanding the examples and having a live demo or at least a screen recording (as it takes an unforeseen amount of time for logs to be generated in the cases where they exist for events. As such, to avoid wasting time waiting for logs will prepare a cut recording.

persons.biography: Chris is a principal security consultant and leads the Cloud Security capability area within WithSecure Consulting. As part of his day to day he leads the global team that deals with various different types of engagements of both a transactional and more bespoke nature. Chris specialises in Microsoft Azure predominantly with GCP and AWS as an additional background.

Security Theater.title: Investigating Industrial Control Systems
Security Theater.abstract:
What to expect when you're all of a sudden called in to investigate a suspected cyber attack against a power plant or an oil refinery? How does such a system even look like from DFIR perspective, and how would an adversary approach attacking them?

In this talk I will teach you some basics of Industrial Control Systems (ICS), explain what a successful cyber attack against an ICS system often looks like, and finally present my personal opinion on how investigating an ICS incident differs from investigating a compromised IT system. If you've never heard about the ICS Cyber Kill Chain or don't know what a PLC or an RTU is, then this talk is for you!
Security Theater.description:
Topics covered in this talk include but are not limited to the following:
* Basics of IT vs. OT & ICS
* ICS terminology
* What does an ICS system look like? What are the similarities and differences to an enterprise IT system?
* IT vs. OT protocols
* Purdue Model
* ICS Cyber Kill Chain with case examples (Stuxnet, Havex)
* How difficult is attacking ICS and why?
* Why security is the number one priority of an operational technology process?
* How does investigating an OT/ICS systems differ from regular IT investigations? Can I utilize my existing tooling and knowledge?

persons.biography: Antti works at NCSC-FI as a Senior Specialist specializing in DFIR and Industrial Control Systems.

Security Theater.title: Ten Security Design Strategies from 2004
Security Theater.abstract: In 2004, I compiled a list of ten security design strategies for software engineering. In this presentation, I revisit the original slide deck and reflect on the last 20 years of software security.
Security Theater.description:
Secure software engineering builds on a foundation of fundamental knowledge of how to build secure systems. In practice, software security frequently fails and often catastrophically.  To be able to break systems you have to understand how they work.  To be able to actually defend systems, you have to understand how to build defendable systems.

I revisit my presentation from 2004 on how to engineer secure systems, and reflect on whether those strategies are still valid today.  I will highlight the slide with anecdotes and examples from my 28-year long career in thinking about how to build secure software systems.

persons.biography: Camillo Särs is CISO at a successful SaaS scale-up. His 25+ years of experience in information and software security includes 21 years at F-Secure and a stint as DPO and CISO for a publicly traded company, where he built the GDPR compliance framework from scratch. Camillo has a deep understanding of how to continuously improve security across a company. From cybersecurity risk management, through security processes and procedures, to security architecture and technologies, he believes security comes down to the adage "People, Process, and Technology". Out of these, People is the most important, as you cannot apply processes and technologies correctly without the right People and competences.

Security Theater.title: Email hacking, attacks and defence today
Security Theater.abstract: Email is the open non-proprietary messaging system on the internet that reaches everyone. Practically all other internet systems rely on email at least as a backup contact or for notifications. Hear about the changing threat landscape of internet email, see current and evolving email threats and attacks, and learn best practises of defence against email abuse.
Security Theater.description: We will bring people up to date on innovative ways people try to abuse and hack email (some fun stories may be included) and best practices and defence methods for various players in the email landscape including senders, receivers and end users. Hear from iki.fi that has run internet email for 30 years since 1995.

persons.biography: Hannu has internet and hacking/infosec experience since the late 1980s. He has been the chair of iki.fi society since 1995. He has long experience from iki.fi related to email from many viewpoints including technical, history, vulnerabilities, standardisation and identity management.

Security Theater.title: Web security is fun (or how I stole your Google Drive files)
Security Theater.abstract: This talk is about a vulnerability in Google Drive. But it's also a talk about web security concepts, how services can be made to interact in unintended ways, and how a few seemingly harmless flaws can be chained to defeat security boundaries.
Security Theater.description:
The story of this talk is a $4133.7 vulnerability chain I found in Google services. Going through the chain, it discusses web security topics such as path traversal, clickjacking, open redirects, security headers, origins etc and demonstrates in which contexts these generally low-impact issues can be combined into a powerful attack.
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1JAkdGVLucrmxx5-od5HtOIyp5phnT2W6BdmnLDMdM9I/edit

Security Theater.title: Living off Microsoft Copilot
Security Theater.abstract:
Whatever your need as a hacker post-compromise, Microsoft Copilot has got you covered. Covertly search for sensitive data and parse it nicely for your use. Exfiltrate it out without generating logs. Most frightening, Microsoft Copilot will help you phish to move lately. Heck, it will even social engineer victims for you!

This talk is a comprehensive analysis of Microsoft copilot taken to red-team-level practicality. We will show how Copilot plugins can be used to install a backdoor into other user’s copilot interactions, allowing for data theft as a starter and AI-based social engineering as the main course. We’ll show how hackers can circumvent built-in security controls which focus on files and data by using AI against them.

Next, we will drop LOLCopilot, a red-teaming tool for abusing Microsoft Copilot as an ethical hacker to do all of the above. The tool works with default configuration in any M365 copilot-enabled tenant.

Finally, we will recommend detection and hardening your can put in place to protect against malicious insiders and threat actors with Copilot access.
Security Theater.description:
Outline:
1. The promise of AI
1.1. A brief intro to the capabilities of Microsoft Copilot and its value proposition for business users
1.2. Making a wish list of things hackers want post-compromise
1.3. Connecting the two together - can we redirect Microsoft Copilot to help us?
2. The basics (heavily demo-based)
2.1. Using copilot to find sensitive data over-shared in the organization
2.2. Using copilot to prepare the perfect phish for corporate users
2.3. Show the limitation of the above., with many queries stopped by existing controls. Are we blocked?
3. A step back - a deep dive into Microsoft Copilot’s architecture
3.1. How Microsoft Copilot is build
3.2.. A deep dive into Microsoft’s security controls over Copilot, including Purview, Conversation Compliance and eDiscovery
4. Circumventing controls
4.1. Prompt injection techniques, hiding in base64, indirect injections and other ways to circumvent controls
4.2. Using the above to find sensitive data, secrets and making copilot generate phishing content.
4.3. But this is all in the scope of our user..
5. Lateral movement (heavily demo-based)
5.1. Planting malicious docs with indirect prompt injection on shared sites
5.2. Exfiltrate data by fooling copilot to send sensitive data out using Bing search
5.3. Can we run on the context of other users? Yes!
6. Copilot plugins - lateral movement in copilot copilot
6.1. Intro to plugins, why they exist
6.2. How plugins work, what they can do, how are they shared, how are they using by copilot
6.3. Designing a malicious plugin that Copilot always chooses to use
6.4. Infecting the organization with our malicious plugin to steal conversation content
7. Taking it a step further - designing a malicious plugin to make copilot phish users to provide their private info
7.1. How does the attack work - the plugin, the requirement from the user (enabling the plugin)
7.2. The victim’s experience
8. Introducing LOLCopilot
8.1. How the tool works to accomplish all of the above
8.2. End to end demo showing: capabilities, victim’s view, and (lack of) logs generated.
9. Defense
9.1. Recommended configuration to harden your tenant
9.2. Detection to catch LOLCopilot

persons.biography:
Inbar has been teaching and lecturing about Internet Security and Reverse Engineering for nearly as long as he has been doing that himself. He started programming at the age of 9 and Reverse Engineering at the age of 14. He spent most of his career in the Internet and Data Security field, and the only reason he's not in jail right now is because he chose the right side of the law at an early age.

Inbar specializes in an outside-the-box approach to analyzing security and finding vulnerabilities, using his extensive experience of close to 30 years. Nowadays, Inbar is the VP of Research at Zenity, the leading platform for securing Business-led Development with Enterprise Copilots and Low-Code/No-Code development.

Michael Bargury is a hacker, builder and a cybersecurity practitioner. He has contributed to revealing novel attack vectors and establishing countermeasures through security standards in cloud, application security, and AI. He is the co-founder and CTO of Zenity, an application security company focused on business enablement in the large enterprise. He leads the OWASP LCNC Top 10 project, writes a column on DarkReading, and regularly delivers research, tools and talks at top conferences including BHUSA, defcon, OWASP and t2.

Security Theater.title: Sounds from the basement: Extreme low-level game cheating
Security Theater.abstract:
In this talk, we will explore an advanced method for cheating in multiplayer PC-based games by leveraging System Management Mode (SMM) as the cheat’s runtime environment. SMM, a privileged execution mode in x86_64 processor architecture, operates at the lowest level of the CPU privilege rings; beneath even the kernel's ring 0 or hypervisor’s “ring -1” - SMM executes in so-called “ring -2”. This makes it an ideal environment for executing anything undetected by traditional detection software typically running in higher privilege rings, be it anti-cheat or anti-virus software. 

We will cover the technical details of how to use SMM, its inherent advantages over other cheating techniques, and the challenges in interfacing with game memory and game object types while remaining undetected from the most established anti-cheat platforms. This talk will include a demonstration of a working game cheat which can bypass modern anti-cheat tools and a deep dive into the potential implications for anti-cheat developers (and other security professionals whose job it is to detect malicious activity in their context). Attendees will leave with a solid understanding of why SMM is a powerful tool for stealth in executing code maliciously and what countermeasures might be required to combat such sophisticated attacks.
Security Theater.description:
# Description
In this talk we are going to give an insight into a rather complex technique, a System Management Mode (SMM) module we've developed for something as simple as game cheats. Since the cheat runs in SMM, a CPU state completely transparent to other operating modes (including ring3, ring0, hypervisor context), the cheat we've developed is inherently very hard to detect by even the most modern, state-of-the-art anti-cheats. In the talk we are going to go over the following points:
 - Introduction to game cheating & anti-cheats, how it is a similar kind of cat & mouse game as malware vs anti-viruses -scene (10 min)
 - Introduction to SMM (10 min)
 - How can SMM be leveraged if you want to cheat in games, what are the obstacles (10 min)
 - Demo of the cheat (5 min)
 - How the cheat is loaded & how it is installed to the system (5 min)
 - Heads-up for anti-cheat devs: how to detect such a cheat, since preventing is currently impossible for the anticheat (5 min)

Below is a more in-depth description/skeleton of the talk

## Introduction to game cheating & anti-cheats
### Groundwork
 - What is cheating in videogames (especially in FPS games)?
 - How to cheat?
	 - What features exist? (Aimbot, ESP (Visual or audio), Wallhacks)
- Basic functionality
	- External (Memory) or Internal cheats (DLL)
- Current state of cheating
	- Normal cheats (ring3)
		- Process started as admin
	- Advanced cheats for games with proper anticheats
		- Kernel driver
		- Direct Memory Access (DMA)
### Modern anticheats
 - Deploy modules in both kernel and usermode
 - Protection itself similar as for Anti virus software
	 - Handle stripping
	 - Event Tracing for Windows (ETW)
	 - Driver callbacks [MS Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/drivers/ddi/ntddk/nf-ntddk-pssetloadimagenotifyroutine)
 - A lot of obfuscation / dynamic modules
	 - Certain more sophisticated checks only loaded & used after a decent amount of in-game reports by other players

## Introduction to SMM
### Execution
 - Basic firmware
	 - SMM modules are stored in and loaded from system firmware (UEFI) image
	 - edk2 (UEFI)
		 - Defacto standard for UEFI images
		 - Sets up a lot of features & "libraries" already so we have it easier
		 - [Github](https://github.com/tianocore/edk2)
 - Runs lower than even the Hypervisor on the system
	 - Show traditional ring slide with extra rings -1 (hypervisor) and -2 (SMM)
	 - SMM's memory cannot be accessed from upper protection rings if the manufacturer did not change the default settings
 - SMM is only entered upon System Management Interrupts (SMIs)#
	- After SMI is received, all cores will enter SMM
	- Rendezvouz will await for all cores by default
	- CPU has to first get setup, on modern plattforms edk2 already takes care of that
		- Sets up Long mode for 64 bit operations
	- State of execution is saved and restored upon entry
		- Similar as in Hypervisors
- SMM has access to all memory and components in the system
	- Depending on the underlying system, OS virtual memory can be a challenge
		- Example: Hypervisor with multi level pagle tables
	- Registers that were saved can also be modified -> change normal operation behavior without it noticing
- Where is the code saved?
	- On a SPI chip on the mainboard (SOIC8 / SOP8 format)
	- Access is possible from external or from the system itself (more on that later)
### Challenges and Limitations
- SMM has to be entered somehow first
- Floating point operations
	- Not set up by edk2
- Normal interrupts
	- Not handled in SMM
### Debugging
- How would you debug this?
	- Deploy the custom firmware in a virtual machine with a hypervisor that supports custom firmware (KVM/QEMU)
		- Introspection from outside the VM
	- Serial communication
		- Some modern boards still have the connector
		- Simply setup the port and send data out, start from a serial "Hello world" SMM module
		- No interrupts required for basic communication (just call outportb, inportb)
	- Debugging features
		- Requires you to actually boot the system
		- Use memory buffer to communicate
		- Example project: 
			- By us [Hermes](https://github.com/pRain1337/hermes)
				- Our version is made to be more stealthy (doesnt execute SMI# by itself, just has a memory buffer)
				- Only compatible with Windows
			- More features, OS support by cr4sh [SmmbackdoorNg](https://github.com/Cr4sh/SmmBackdoorNg)


## How to use SMM for a game cheat
### Why even use SMM for a game cheat?
- Better question, why not?
	- Stealth is built in, its perfect
	- SMM exists on every computer already altough it can be considered legacy by some
	- Technique itself gets talked about in the game cheating scene, but only very few projects released
		- [ekknod](https://github.com/ekknod/smm)
			- After installation, put PC in sleep mode to trigger a SMI and set a variable in the game to enable ESP
		- [Zepta](https://github.com/Oliver-1-1/SmmInfect)
			- Similar to Hermes, less features
- Our thought for this project:
	- Instead of using the existing techniques which are known by anticheats, use something completly new
		- In our opinion, hiding something always introduces a larger detection surface than not hiding at all
### Disclaimer
 - Project was done in the last year for educational and scientific purposes and as a challenge to bypass the most modern and most advanced anti-cheats
### What do we want to implement?
 - Typical features (Aimbot, Sound ESP, Radar)
 - Goal is that everything is running fully in SMM
	 - No execution required in the underlying operating system
### How to implement?
#### Pain points
- We need to get execution in SMM
	- If we run everything in SMM, we need a lot of SMI because modern games happen real-time - we need to update data at a high frequency
	- Known possibilities:
		- Intel PCH features timers that will regulary trigger a SMI
		- Either they are not that fast (only a couple per second) or they halt the system on modern chipsets
			- We requested for manuals that explain the undocumented parts of SMI generation in public specs, but Intel required us to sign an NDA for further information...
- We need to interact with the user/system to actually achieve a benefit
- No interrupts -> cant just stay in SMM and overwrite when there is incoming data
	- Wanting it to be stealthy -> no component running on the operating system
	- Direct modification of data in kernel would work, but it would enlargen the detection surface and therefore we would get caught sooner or later
#### Solution
- SMI generation on XHCI events!
	- Initial idea presented by Joshua Schiffman and David Kaplan (The SMM Rootkit Revisited: Fun with USB, 2014)
		- Initial approach would modify interrupt registers in the XHCI, but we found a much better feature
	-	Intel PCH and XHCI controller feature built-in bits to leave the normal interrupt flow and generate a SMI on each USB event
		-	We get a lot of execution (as gaming mice run at high frequency) and even get the execution exactly when there is incoming data!
	-	This allows us to parse the structures of the XHCI, find the right USB device, find the USB endpoint that is used for data transfer and find the transfer buffer used by it
	-	Thus, we can modify incoming/outgoing data from USB packets without the operating system noticing
		-	Example 1: a mouse
			-	HID protocol used, can just modify the x,y coordinates for an aimbot
		- Example 2: a sound device (speaker, headphones...)
			- Sound data is transported out, we can just write data to produce noise which can easily be distinguished by the user
	- Any drawbacks? Yes...
		- Modern USB devices (especially gaming mouses) have a high polling rate, means we have to be quick in SMM as we get a lot of CPU SMM <--> userspace context switches!


## Demo
- Prepare a computer where the game cheat is already installed on the SPI chip
	- Installing otherwise might take 10 minutes and sometimes the SOIC8 clip dont hold onto properly
 - Connect USB speaker to computer
 - Connect serial cable to second device for debug output
 - Start game (Counter-Strike 2) and go to a local server
 - Wait a couple second until debug output shows it worked -> noise should be heard when hovering over an enemy behind a wall


## How to install?
 - Depends on how modern the computer is
	 - Installing from operating system gets harder, but is not impossible
- Way that nearly always works for installation:
	- SOIC8 Clip and using Flashrom
	- Some mainboard dont have the chips exposed or other formats -> can get complicated


## How to detect such a cheat?
 - Some possibilities which can show clear proof that a cheat is actually used
	 - More possibilities exist, but they dont show a cheat is used, more that the SPI was modified
### Memory side channel honeypot
- Original idea from [Everdox](https://web.archive.org/web/20211229210102/https:/twitter.com/nickeverdox/status/1476295914423656456) (Anti-Cheat Developer at Riot)
- Implementation by [h33p](https://github.com/h33p/side-channels)
- Uses analytics on the latency of CPU cache lines
- Basic terms:
	- Create a memory honeypot in the game memory
	- Modify the game so the honeypot is in the actual structures (example a fake player object) and that the real game would never actually access this object
		- Now monitor the latency of accessing that cache line
			- If the latency goes down sometime it means that something on the system is accessing it
	- Now repeat this, plant multiple honeypots and if the behavior keeps repeating, it means something is repeatedly parsing the game player structures
	- Simple fix is disabling the cache in SMM before accessing it
		- Performance loss is noticeable so no real fix
### SPI dumping & analyzing
- DXE to SMM vulnerabilities exist, but it is more likely that the cheat is stored in the SPI chip itself
- Basically read the content of the chip on the mainboard and check for malicious modules
	- Commercial tools exist for exactly this
	- Then just parse the SPI dump and extract the modules (UEFITool / UEFIExtract)
	- One problem:
		- Modules are not signed / certified, you will have to build the database of known modules yourself
 - Cheat could prevent this by blocking SPI reads using PCH features (Protected range registers)


## Future work
- What other stuff would be possible using SMM?
	- Simple backdoors for HyperV debugging, Cr4sh [SmmbackdoorNg](https://github.com/Cr4sh/SmmBackdoorNg)
	- System introspection framework [Spectre](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/6575343)
	- Cloud resource usage monitoring [Scotch](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-66332-6_18)
	- Runtime I/O device security checks [IOCheck](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/6615523)
- With edk2 the barrier of entry is relatively low, hardest thing is getting the compilation working one time!


# Bonus slides (not actual content of the presentation)
## Introduction to SMM
- Where is the SMM code saved?
	- SPI chip
		- SOIC8 / SOP8 Chips
	 - Access possible from the operation system itself (MMIO / IO) 
## How to install the cheat
- EFI Shell / afudos / manufacturer tools
	- Worked in the past years, now limited on most devices using Protected range registers
- Mainboard features
	- Asus Flashback
		- Exists on their more premium line
		- Specific USB port for flashing
		- Plug USB with image with proper name in and press the flashback button on a turned off system
		- Preboot environment will not check anything and happily flash the modified UEFI firmware with a malicious SMM module
## How to detect the cheat
- Methods which are only an indication but not clear proof
### MSR_SMI_COUNT
- Intel provides this neat feature, shows you the amount of SMI since power
	- Full SMM cheat will be running a lot of times in SMM -> high amount
	- MSR Spoof not possible by itself using just SMM / PCH features
		 - Only by using a hypervisor or modifying the OS
	 - Means: No clear evidence of cheat, but suspicious
### Time delay
- Similar as how an anticheat might detect a hypervisor
- Time spent in SMM can be detected by analyzing TSC or other clocks (HPC)
- Nowadays harder to run due to HVCI which forces a Hypervisor
- Means: No clear evidence of cheat, but suspicious
### TPM measurement for boot PCR
- Can be used to measure the SPI even if the read fails
- Shows a deviation from the expected hash

## How to prevent such a cheat
### Intel Bios Guard and Boot Guard
- System would not boot/flash a modified image
- Mostly implemented on business devices, not mainboard for build-your-own-pc (Mostly used by gamers)
- There will always be manufacturers that won't implement it, as it means more expenses and end users (gamers) don't require it
- Means: Can't be enforced for everyone by an Anticheat, but for selected people (when playing for money as example)
### SPI Protected range registers (PRR)
- Only blocks the installing of the cheat, nowadays done by most manufacturers
	- Prevents flashing from the OS 
	- Manufacturer still needs to support flashing from OS
		- Possible exploitation of manufacturer tools to flash modified images!
- Makes the effort bigger the user needs to do to install the cheat
### SMI Transfer Monitor (STM)
- Basically a hypervisor for SMM
- Can restrict what SMM modules are allowed to access etc.
- Might come in the future, but manufacturer will take a long time until it is deployed on all systems
- Paper: PSEC2018-STM-PE-Eugene-Myers

persons.biography:
Diego Caminada has a strong background in general IT technologies and works as a Security Analyst during the day where he helps defend the infrastructures of various companies while studying low-level and offensive technologies at night to stay one step ahead of future threats.  
He is a admirer of the underground game hacking scene due to the anonymous nature of the scene and the advanced techniques deployed in the endless cat and mouse game, which is game cheating.

Jussi Hietanen has a strong background in security engineering and software development - his current job title is IT Manager, but he has worked on embedded systems, vulnerability management, and security automation. Jussi is passionate about open-source technologies and cybersecurity innovation. He holds an M.Sc. degree in Computer Science from Aalto University.

Security Forum.title: Security safeguards in continuous integration
Security Forum.abstract:
Automate robust security measures directly into your continuous integration pipeline. This hands-on workshop starts your path for mastering automated security checks and strengthening your projects security posture from the get-go!

## Prerequisites

- Text editor
- git
- GitHub Account and Public repository

## Topics

- How the GitHub Actions work
- What is a good security test in continuous integration
- How to analyse your code against defects
- How to analyse your dependencies against known vulnerabilities
- How to check your open source licenses
- How to scan your code for secret leaks
- How to scan your infrastructure as code for misconfigurations
- How to generate bill of materials
- How to check http security headers status from a website
- Implementing branch guards

## Who should attend
- Security Engineers
- Software Developers
- Anyone interested

persons.biography: Joona Immonen is a cloud security consultant with background as a developer. He has been early adopter in both cloud and DevSecOps. Lately he has been focusing on delivering secure cloud solutions on Azure as a cloud and security architect.

Pasi Huuhka is a Microsoft Azure MVP with a background as a DevOps Architect, Developer and a Sysadmin.

He has been working with Microsoft products since 2013 and has broad knowledge of Azure services ranging from IaaS all the way to serverless offerings. Along the years he has had the opportunity of developing software and automating deployments for 100+ customers ranging from startups to large enterprises.

His current focus is on SRE, DevOps and App Dev on Azure, learning new things while teaching others.

Are you interested in exploring others' LED projects? Come blink and beep with us! The meetup begins with an introduction to LED-elements seen in the space. After that, the program includes open discussions with like-minded individuals. Feel free to bring your setup or story and share it with fellow tech enthusiasts.
